text: - Hello.
- Hello, hola.
(Speaking in foreign language)
(speaking in foreign language)
- And these are our students.
Say hello.
- Hello
(upbeat music)
- At Lilu, we build smart garments
to make life easier for new mums.
In particular we're focused
on making breast pumping easier
and more comfortable.
- I'm co-founder at Zwende.com,

a maker to consumer platform
for creative products
and artistic experiences from small makers
all over India to consumers globally.

- Seenit is a video
crowdsourcing platform,
we allow anyone within a business
to start easily creating video
by directing and collecting content
from anyone anywhere in the world.
- Help.ngo has worked around the world

to assist local communities
and international actors,
really to respond to emergencies.
Dispatching emergency vehicles in Haiti,

risk reduction mapping
using drones in Mozambique.
- Polaris is a leading nonpartisan NGO

that works to end sex
and labor trafficking
and restore freedom to survivors.

Human trafficking is a $150
billion criminal industry
with 25 million victims worldwide.
- So with the pandemic,
the number one problem is trying
to detect people who have COVID-19.

What we're trying to do
is see if we can detect it

prior to symptom onset
with a simple smartwatch.
- Here at Blue Mountain Community College
in northeastern Oregon,
we're training the next generation
of data center technicians.
These are the technicians that keep
the cloud running smoothly.

- Labs is Ryanair's IT hub
where everything you see
on our website and mobile app is built.

- Our goal is to bring
real marketable skills

to formerly incarcerated
injustice impacted individual
by teaching them full stack development.
- Lalaland, nothing to do with the movie,
is actually an Amsterdam based startup

that solves a massive
problem of people feeling
underrepresented while shopping online.

We do so by using AI to
create synthetic humans
for fashion eCommerce brands.
(upbeat music)

- I started Lilu because
I fundamentally believe
that technology can and should be used
to improve people's health
and to bring joy into people's lives.

- It's extremely gratifying to
see small makers and artists
who are unable to do things on their own
find a way to earn a livelihood
and sustain their business.

- One of my biggest motivators
is seeing the stories

that our customers collect
through the platform.
Stories captured in people's homes,
from offices around the world,

from remote or even
inaccessible locations.
Before the cloud,

this would have been insanely
expensive to have captured

and in some cases would
have been impossible.

This is leading to much
more diverse stories

being listened to being
heard and being championed.

- What motivates me is when
I meet one of our alumni

and I hear about how
much they love their job,

many of them are working
at AWS data centers.

- Every day, I go to work
knowing that actually
what we're doing will make a difference.
- I'm living proof of the difference

that Justice Through Code
can make in their lives.
- Our goal was really to bring health care
to the entire planet
with simple devices.
- We empower both brands and consumers
to pluralise the beauty standard

by making the web as diverse
as the market we serve.
(upbeat music)

- Cloud technology is such a
huge part of today's society.
- This allows a small maker
to now compete with larger brands
with store fronts that look and seem
as large as any other large brand.

This is what the cloud
has enabled us to do.

- What's really interesting
about breastfeeding

and breast pumping is
that we can accompany her,
we can guide her,
we can give her lactation insights,

connecting her with her health
providers in a timely manner,
getting ahead of problems
and all of this is now possible

by connecting physical
devices with digital products.

Cloud computing plays such
an integral role in this.

- The Trafficking Hotline
is a highly complex
technical operation that has generated
the single largest dataset
on human trafficking in the United States.

- Pulling data from millions
and millions of people,
running algorithms

and then alert them when
they get a stress signal,
which could be COVID-19.
In order to do this for millions
if not billions of people,
you absolutely have to have the cloud

because it's just too
computationally intensive
and we wanna do all this in real time.

- We're one of the
world's busiest websites,

we need a solution that
be scalable, flexible
and allows us to add new features
as customers' demands change over time.
- We hope that cloud continues to grow
because the more it grows,

the more job opportunities
that are in technology
for my students and our alumni.
(upbeat music)

- Technology has the
opportunity to stop emergencies

from turning into disasters
in the first place.

- With waste and inefficiencies
in like our households.

- Use technology to
improve engine designs,

air traffic control,
flight planning routes,
every single thing we can do
to reduce our CO2 emissions
is fundamentally what we do at Ryanair.

- If I was to put technology
to work to solve one problem,
it would be inequality.
- At Polaris, we are fighting for a world
where the powerful cannot exploit
the vulnerable for profits.
- So the same way that technology is used
to get products and services
from the far reaches of the world,

technology can be used to
end poverty and world hunger

in the same areas that many
of these products come from.
- Biases within classification tools.

And biases could exist
either racial biases

or either from different
body positivity biases.
- Ultimately we want to be able
to really improve people's health care
one person at a time.

- With cloud computing
continuing to evolve,
we can do more faster,
more efficiently for more consumers.

- We really need to
address these global crises
and I think AWS is the right company
at the right time

with the right tools to
really get this done.
(gentle music)
